frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Three solid conducting spheres are connected with two very long, thin conducting wires, as shown. They are all initially neutral; then a charge of <math alttext="12 Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is transferred to the leftmost sphere. Enough time elapses that the spheres achieve electrostatic equilibrium. Assume <math alttext="d is much greater than R " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>></mo><mo>></mo><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and that the system of spheres and wires is isolated from any external forces. (a) Calculate the charge on each sphere. Express your answers in terms of <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Rank the spheres according to their surface charge density, with 1 indicating the greatest surface charge density. If two spheres have the same value, then give them the same ranking._____ Sphere <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> _____ Sphere <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> _____ Sphere <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

(c) The magnitudes of the electric field at the surfaces of spheres <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="E sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="E sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. Calculate the ratio <math alttext="E sub A over E sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Is the tension in the left wire greater than, less than, or equal to the tension in the right wire? Assume nonelectric forces are negligible._____ Greater than _____ Less than _____ Equal toJustify your answer.The wire between spheres <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> breaks. Assume the force of gravity is negligible.

(e) Determine the new charges on spheres <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer.

(f) After the wire breaks, sphere <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> accelerates away from the other two spheres.i. The arrow must start on, and point away from, the dot.

ii.
